tossups.question_sanitized: H. Allen Orr’s study of this phenomenon in haploid and diploid Chlamydomonas (kluh-MID-oh-MOH-nuss) cast doubt upon Fisher’s theory that this phenomenon evolved due to selection on modifier loci for deleterious mutations. Total genetic variance can be partitioned into an additive component and components driven by epistasis and this phenomenon. When succeeded by the word “negative,” the word for this phenomenon can describe gain-of-function mutations that act antagonistically to the wild-type. Haploinsufficiency can cause the incomplete form of this phenomenon, and A and B blood types exhibit its “co-” form. For 10 points, name this inheritance pattern denoted with capital letters, in which one allele masks the effect of another allele at the same locus, in contrast to recessiveness.

bonuses.leadin_sanitized: Lee Lozano’s “Dropout Piece” shocked the art world by promising this action, and Tehching Hsieh committed to do this for his 1985 to 1986 “One Year Performance.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: boring [or “I will not make any more boring art.”]
parts_sanitized: Give this action, which van Gogh implicitly did by committing suicide. Agnes Martin did this for eighteen months so she could travel North America in solitude.

This artist chose to stop making art so he could pursue his passion for chess, but it later turned out he had been working on a final piece in secret, Étant donnés (ay-TAWN duh-NAY). He also created “readymades” such as In Advance of a Broken Arm and other found objects.
A John Baldessari piece invited students from the Nova Scotia School of Art and Design to join him in repeatedly writing a declaration to not make any more art of this type.

bonuses.leadin: An employee of this institution, Michael Fish, was widely mocked for joking that there was no hurricane on the way prior to the Great Storm of 1987. For 10 points each:
bonuses.leadin_sanitized: An employee of this institution, Michael Fish, was widely mocked for joking that there was no hurricane on the way prior to the Great Storm of 1987. For 10 points each:
answers: The Met Office [or the Meteorological Office; prompt on descriptive answers; do not accept or prompt on “BBC” or “British Broadcasting Corporation”]
answers_sanitized: The Met Office [or the Meteorological Office; prompt on descriptive answers; do not accept or prompt on “BBC” or “British Broadcasting Corporation”]
parts: Name this institution founded by former Beagle captain Robert FitzRoy, which issues things the Shipping Forecast and Severe Weather Warnings.

The Storm Tides Warning Service in the Met Office was created in 1953 after a massive North Sea flood devastated both the UK and this country, which experienced flooding when dykes in the province of Zeeland were breached.

A “Free” university in this European city maintains a meteorological institute that has since the 1950s named all high and low pressure areas affecting central Europe. In November 2002 the institute here began the “Adopt-a-Vortex” plan allowing people to buy naming rights for systems.
parts_sanitized: Name this institution founded by former Beagle captain Robert FitzRoy, which issues things the Shipping Forecast and Severe Weather Warnings.

The Storm Tides Warning Service in the Met Office was created in 1953 after a massive North Sea flood devastated both the UK and this country, which experienced flooding when dykes in the province of Zeeland were breached.

A “Free” university in this European city maintains a meteorological institute that has since the 1950s named all high and low pressure areas affecting central Europe. In November 2002 the institute here began the “Adopt-a-Vortex” plan allowing people to buy naming rights for systems.

bonuses.leadin: This character’s last words before dying are “You were right, old hoss; you were right,” as he thinks of an “old-timer” at Sulphur Creek. For 10 points each:
bonuses.leadin_sanitized: This character’s last words before dying are “You were right, old hoss; you were right,” as he thinks of an “old-timer” at Sulphur Creek. For 10 points each:
answers: the protagonist of “To Build a Fire” [accept any answer indicating this is the character in “To Build a Fire”]
Jack London [or John Griffith London; or John Griffith Chaney]
answers_sanitized: the protagonist of “To Build a Fire” [accept any answer indicating this is the character in “To Build a Fire”]
Jack London [or John Griffith London; or John Griffith Chaney]
parts: Identify this unnamed character who dies at the end of a 1908 story after foolishly ignoring various warnings. After his death, his equally unnamed dog runs off.
This author of “To Build a Fire” also set his novel The Call of the Wild in the Yukon.

This non-fiction 1913 novel by London describes his addiction to alcohol. Supposedly containing the first recorded example of a drunk seeing “pink elephants,” this book takes its name a British folk song about the personification of a cereal crop used to make alcohol.
parts_sanitized: Identify this unnamed character who dies at the end of a 1908 story after foolishly ignoring various warnings. After his death, his equally unnamed dog runs off.
This author of “To Build a Fire” also set his novel The Call of the Wild in the Yukon.

This non-fiction 1913 novel by London describes his addiction to alcohol. Supposedly containing the first recorded example of a drunk seeing “pink elephants,” this book takes its name a British folk song about the personification of a cereal crop used to make alcohol.

bonuses.leadin: The Los Angeles Times claimed a photo of this man made him look “as if he were dreamily contemplating some outrage against conventional morality.” For 10 points each:
bonuses.leadin_sanitized: The Los Angeles Times claimed a photo of this man made him look “as if he were dreamily contemplating some outrage against conventional morality.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Truman Capote [Truman Garcia Capote; or Truman Streckfus Parsons]
Dill Harris [or Charles Baker Harris; or Harris]
parts: Name this author, who was photographed intensely gazing into the camera while reclining for the dust jacket of a 1948 novel. That book by this man takes place at the mansion Skully’s Landing.

Twelve years after the publication of Other Voices, Other Rooms, a younger version of Capote was fictionalized as this character in the 1960 novel To Kill a Mockingbird. This character is a boy who visits Macomb (MAKE-um) every summer and befriends Scout.
Until the controversial 2015 publication of Go Set a Watchman, To Kill a Mockingbird was the only published novel by this author, a longtime friend of Capote.

bonuses.leadin: This character invites himself over to Longbourn in a letter where he says: “I flatter myself that my present overtures of good will are highly commendable.” For 10 points each:
bonuses.leadin_sanitized: This character invites himself over to Longbourn in a letter where he says: “I flatter myself that my present overtures of good will are highly commendable.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this pompous clergyman who reads Fordyce’s sermons to a half-willing audience. When he learns that the woman he is hitting on “will soon be engaged,” he goes after her sister instead without hesitation.
Collins ends up going after this second Bennett sister, who rejects him. She ends up deepening her relationship with the rich, but aloof, Mr. Darcy.
Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy end up marrying in this Jane Austen novel, in which Lydia elopes with Mr. Wickham and Jane marries Charles Bingley.

bonuses.leadin: The nearest example of one of these objects is Luhman 16, a binary system of two of them. For 10 points each:
bonuses.leadin_sanitized: The nearest example of one of these objects is Luhman 16, a binary system of two of them. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this type of substellar object which is very massive, possibly large enough to fuse deuterium and lithium, but not large enough to trigger hydrogen-to-helium fusion as in main sequence stars.
Brown dwarfs are thought to range between 13 and 65 times the mass of this planet, which is the largest in our solar system and a stormy gas giant.

This type of planet forms when a gas giant is close to a star, which strips away its gaseous bulk in a process known as “hydrodynamic escape,” leaving only a rocky core. COROT-7b is the first exoplanet found that seems to be one of these planets.
